abstract: Private equity firms and hedge funds are trying to prove to regulators that they are capable of running failed banks, where big profits are possible, by recapitalizing troubled banks that have yet to fail.
snippet: Private equity firms and hedge funds are trying to prove to regulators that they are capable of running failed banks, where big profits are possible, by recapitalizing troubled banks that have yet to fail.
lead_paragraph: 12:55 p.m. | Corrected Private equity firms and hedge funds are still trying to take over community banks a year after the government instituted strict new rules that made it more difficult for nonbanking institutions to acquire failed banks. But the takeovers have been slow going, Matthew Goldstein of Reuters reports, with fewer than two dozen of the more than 236 banks shut by the government since January 2009 sold at auction to private equity firms and hedge funds.

headline.main: Buyout Groups Persist in Pursuing Failing Banks
